ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: ASL grammar and sentence structures, Deaf culture, ASL art forms (literature, poetry, music), current issues facing the Deaf population, and knowledge of disability more broadly
More on ASL, Deaf culture, and learning styles that work best for me!
more about ASL!
Increased fluency in American Sign Language, depth of knowledge of Deaf history/culture
I improved my ASL skills so much this semester! My receptive skills are a lot stronger than last semester, and general communication feels easier and more natural than it ever has.
ASL culture, formal communication skills.
Practice with ASL, formal presentation skills
Deaf culture, art, culture; formal presentation, storytelling, and poetry in ASL

I developed my conversational and presentations ASL communication skills to a proficient level. I learned so much more about the Deaf community and culture, especially through the semester service project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I think the ASL department approaches language learning in a very approachable and low stress way which makes it easier to actually learn the language rather than stress about assignments, the professors are really really knowledgeable and helpful and I found the assignments to aid my learning a lot
Weaknesses: I think there still needs to be some work done on adding more structure to the service projects, there have definitely been improvements but I think if it's going to be a required part of the grade it needs to be a little more structured
The 4 day a week and learning-centered classroom over grading work very well. Sometimes repetitive.

strengths - class community, lower workload, service projects
weaknesses - seemed like we were running out of time every day, sometimes instructions for assignments were unclear
The course is unorganized at times, and the nature of the assignments can be unclear.
Great course!

I really liked the combination of lecture and small group discussion/practice in ASL IV! I also enjoyed the emphasis on poetry and translation later in the semester. I would have enjoyed more consistent work with service projects (i.e. weekly check-ins to talk about tasks) as opposed to having work building up at the end of the semester, which I think can tend to happen in ASL courses.

Strengths: voice off policy, lots of ways to interact with other ASL students and the Deaf community, fun in-class activities
Weaknesses: I had a larger class which was a little bit rough sometimes. It took a lot of time for everyone to say how they were and things like that. Also there would be quite a lot of people missing from class some days which was hard if we were doing group work.

Meeting 4 times a week is definitely helpful and relevant to developing ASL communication skills. Classes were always engaging and I always enjoyed attending. There was enough guidance for the semester service project and I felt there was enough support for outside the classroom learning. I would have appreciated better communication outlets with my professor and student peers, such as creating a class groupchat in the beginning of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it, I think it really does improve your ASL skills and helps you build community with other people involved in ASL at Yale. I'm glad I continued with the ASL program and would encourage other ASL students to do so as well
Yes
My fav dept at Yale! Def the best language to get your requirement done with, but more than that a community + new way of looking at the world!
yes for sure - the ASL program is so good for so many reasons
Yes!
Yes!! The ASL program is wonderful  I highly highly recommend all classes!
Yes ASL is the best department at Yale take it.

I believe that absolutely anyone can learn ASL and that everyone should take it. It has brought me the most enjoyment these past two years and the faculty, as well as how they engage with the ASL community at Yale, is absolutely immaculate.
Yes! The ASL professors are great. This is a fun class to get more involved in the Deaf community and culture.

Yes, a million times! The ASL department is so caring and appreciative of students. When you learn ASL you become apart of such an inviting and positive community of students and staff at Yale. You learn more than just the language, you learn about the Deaf community, the culture, accessibility and so much more.
